suite.name: Registration

kw.name: Begin Web Test
kw.doc: Operations that are repeated at suite setup

kw.name: Convert Suite Variables To Correct Types
kw.doc: This keyword is needed because parameters passed by command line to robot (i.e. -v variable_name:value) are of string types. In run command we pass 2 parameters to robot: robot -d Results/ -v DATA_SET_LENGTH:100 -v USE_EXISTING_FORM_DATA_SET:True -v BROWSER:chromium -P CustomLibs Tests/ So, we have the following variables passed as strings: - DATA_SET_LENGTH:100 - USE_EXISTING_FORM_DATA_SET:True We need to convert: - DATA_SET_LENGTH to int (i.e. integer) - USE_EXISTING_FORM_DATA_SET to bool (i.e. boolean) Later these values will be used while loading DataManager.robot resource.

kw.name: Import Resource
kw.doc: Imports a resource file with the given path.

kw.name: Load Locator Resources
kw.doc: Depending on the BROWSER variable's value, it loads the corresponding locator resource files This keyword enables us to choose the right folder (e.g. Locators/Chromium), inside which we expect to have the correct *Locators.resource files. Each *Locators.resource file (e.g. Locators/Chromium/LoginPageLocators.resource) contains the correct locators for the page in question (e.g. Login Page) and for the browser (e.g. Chromium ) in question

kw.name: Import Locators
kw.doc: Given the locators_path, which points at Resources/Locators/<Browser> directory (e.g. Resources/Locators/Chromium), this keyword loads all *Locators.resource files inside the directory. This is due to fact that the system under test's DOM can be different for different browsers. Imagine that Registration Page has differengt DOM structure for Firefox and Chrome. Then we have to have 2 different REGISTRATION_PAGE_LOCATORs defined for each browser Have a look at - Resources/Locators/Chromium/RegistrationPageLocators.resource - Resources/Locators/Firefox/RegistrationPageLocators.resource So we would have to import different locators for different browsers via this keyword

kw.name: New Page
kw.doc: Open a new Page. A Page is the Playwright equivalent to a tab. See `Browser, Context and Page` for more information about Page concept. Returns a stable identifier for the created page.
kw.msg: Successfully initialized new page object and opened url: about:blank

kw.name: Run Keyword And Ignore Error
kw.doc: Runs the given keyword with the given arguments and ignores possible error.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

Must contain at least one character from [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9] and [!?.]'}, 'first_name': {'value': 'Helena!.?', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'Each first name must contain only characters from the set [a-zA-Z]. First names must be seperated by a a single space. First names must have at least 2 characters'}, 'last_name': {'value': 'Cuzdan123!?.', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'Each last name must contain only characters from the set [a-zA-Z]. kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.arg: 'Could not calculate next page from registration form data'

Must contain at least one character from [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9] and [!?.]'}, 'first_name': {'value': 'Helena Margaretha', 'isValid': True}, 'last_name': {'value': 'Holm!.?', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'Each last name must contain only characters from the set [a-zA-Z]. Last names must be seperated by a a single space. Last names must have at least 2 characters'}, 'phone_number': {'value': '+358abc662712xyz', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'phone number can only contain numbers [0-9] and optionally a single plus sign at the beginning indicating the country code'}}

kw.name: Run Keyword And Ignore Error

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

Space character is not allowed'}, 'password': {'value': 'ABCD0123', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'Min 8 characters. Must contain at least one character from [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9] and [!?.]'}, 'first_name': {'value': 'Helena Margaretha', 'isValid': True}, 'last_name': {'value': 'Wi X', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'Each last name must contain only characters from the set [a-zA-Z]. Last names must be seperated by a a single space. Last names must have at least 2 characters'}, 'phone_number': {'value': '+358abc662712xyz', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'phone number can only contain numbers [0-9] and optionally a single plus sign at the beginning indicating the country code'}}

kw.name: Click
kw.doc: Simulates mouse click on the element found by ``selector``.

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Evaluate
kw.doc: Evaluates the given expression in Python and returns the result.

kw.name: Get Url

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Fail
kw.arg: 'Could not calculate next page from registration form data'
kw.doc: Fails the test with the given message and optionally alters its tags.

kw.arg: Registration (with index: ${index}) succeeded with the following form data:

Must contain at least one character from [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9] and [!?.]'}, 'first_name': {'value': 'Helena Margaretha', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'Each first name must contain only characters from the set [a-zA-Z]. First names must be seperated by a a single space. First names must have at least 2 characters'}, 'last_name': {'value': 'Holm', 'isValid': True}, 'phone_number': {'value': '+358abc662712xyz', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'phone number can only contain numbers [0-9] and optionally a single plus sign at the beginning indicating the country code'}}

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.arg: 'Could not calculate next page from registration form data'
kw.doc: Fails the test with the given message and optionally alters its tags.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Fail
kw.arg: 'Could not calculate next page from registration form data'
kw.doc: Fails the test with the given message and optionally alters its tags.

kw.msg: {'username': {'value': '#¤% 23!', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'Minimum 8 characters required. Space character is not allowed'}, 'password': {'value': '012!?.AB012!?.AB012!?.', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'Min 8 characters. Must contain at least one character from [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9] and [!?.]'}, 'first_name': {'value': 'Helena Margaretha', 'isValid': True}, 'last_name': {'value': 'Cuzdan123!?.', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'Each last name must contain only characters from the set [a-zA-Z]. Last names must be seperated by a a single space. Last names must have at least 2 characters'}, 'phone_number': {'value': '+358abc662712xyz', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'phone number can only contain numbers [0-9] and optionally a single plus sign at the beginning indicating the country code'}}

kw.name: Run Keyword And Ignore Error
kw.doc: Runs the given keyword with the given arguments and ignores possible error.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.arg: 'Could not calculate next page from registration form data'

Must contain at least one character from [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9] and [!?.]'}, 'first_name': {'value': 'Helena Margaretha', 'isValid': True}, 'last_name': {'value': 'W X', 'isValid': False, 'expected_error': 'Each last name must contain only characters from the set [a-zA-Z]. kw.name: Register
kw.doc: For a list of registration_form_data examples, have a look at TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json Note that registration_form_data is a dictionary. This keyword fills in the form with the given data in the registration_form_data dictionary. The presses "Register" button in the registration page. The system under test is supposed to check if the data entered into the form is valid: - If not valid, registration page is still shown - If the form data is valid, then login page is to be shown If the form data is not valid, then the registration page is supposed to show only the first error for the field from top to bottom. Refer to "Check Registration Form Error Messages" for more information

kw.name: Calculate Next Page
kw.doc: In order registration_form_data to be valid, all the fields' in registration_form_data must be valid. If registration_form_data is valid we expect the system under test to redirect to login page. If registration_form_data is invalid, we expect the system under test to stay in registration page.

kw.name: Check Registration Form Error Messages
kw.doc: Before this keyword is called, the form is filled with registration_form_data and Register button is clicked. registration_form_data is a dictionary containing 5 (UI) elements: - username - password - first_name - last_name - phone_number Refer to TestData/RegisterFormDataSet.json for a list of registration_form_data examples. In this keyword, we check registration_form_data's elements in the above given priority order as such: - If the element in registration_form_data (e.g. username) is invalid, then we expect to see its custom error message - If the custom error message is shown, then we quit this keyword. - Otherwise, we fail the keyword with telling which custom error message is missing.

kw.name: Close Browser
kw.doc: Closes the current browser. Activated browser is set to first active browser. Closes all context and pages belonging to this browser. See `Browser, Context and Page` for more information about Browser and related concepts.

kw.name: Stop Web Application
kw.doc: This terminates all the flask processes created by "Re-Start Web Application With No Users" keyword.

kw.name: Terminate All Processes
kw.doc: Terminates all still running processes started by this library.
